page.title: 03Ecology 2; Upton Snodsbury
page.content: Many of the hedgerows are trimmed low by mechanical hedge-cutters and therefore are not so picturesque. There are small areas of deciduous trees on farms and in hedges. Some re-planting of trees is taking place. Footpaths and bridlepaths are fairly well-maintained and efforts are being made to sign-post them. Footpaths are a subject of some discussion owing to the conflicting needs of walkers and farmers. Worcestershire has an exceptional mileage of foot- and bridlepaths. There is an abundance of wild-life: foxes, hares, rabbits and squirrels. Many species of birds are found, with large numbers of rooks, wood-pigeons, starlings and lapwings.
